title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998". The Congress finds that there are over 600 Federal financial assistance programs with duplicative and burdensome administrative requirements, hindering cost-effective service delivery. Streamlining these procedures will improve services to the public. The purposes of this Act are to improve the effectiveness and performance of Federal financial assistance programs, simplify application and reporting requirements, enhance service delivery to the public, and promote greater coordination among service providers. In this Act, key definitions include Director as the head of the Office of Management and Budget, Federal agency as any agency defined under title 5, Federal financial assistance as assistance provided to non-Federal entities, local government as a political subdivision of a State, and non-Federal entity as a State, local government, or nonprofit organization. A nonprofit organization is defined as an entity operated for public interest, not for profit, and uses proceeds to maintain operations. A State is defined as any state within the United States and its territories. The curr_chunk defines terms related to governmental entities, including Tribal government and uniform administrative rule. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment to streamline application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, and allow electronic application and reporting for financial assistance programs. The agency must ensure recipients of Federal financial assistance provide timely, complete, and high-quality information in response to reporting requirements. Specific annual goals and objectives must be established to measure performance, with noncompliance reasons reported to relevant committees for consultation. After setting specific annual goals and objectives for performance measurement, agencies must publish their plans in the Federal Register for public comment and hold public forums. The lead official must consult with non-Federal entities during plan development and implementation, including State, local, and tribal governments. The Director may grant up to a 12-month extension for plan development and implementation for noncompliant agencies after consultation with relevant committees. Each Federal agency must submit a plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE DIRECTOR. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and non-Federal entities, shall direct and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This system will allow non-Federal entities to apply for, manage, and report on funding from multiple programs administered by different agencies. An interagency process is established to streamline and simplify administrative procedures for Federal financial assistance programs, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance timeliness and completeness of data. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to improve the timeliness, completeness, and quality of information received by Federal agencies from recipients of Federal financial assistance. Agencies must submit information for review regarding their implementation of the Act, and the Director has the authority to exempt agencies or programs with few financial assistance programs from the Act's requirements. The Director maintains a list of exempted agencies for Federal financial assistance programs, available on OMB's website. SEC. 7. EVALUATION. The Director shall contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government. Federal agencies, State, local, and tribal governments, and nonprofit organizations are involved in implementing this Act. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION.

Federal agencies can gather information for review of activities assisted by Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW.

No judicial review of compliance with this Act. No right enforceable by administrative or judicial action.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS.

This Act does not deviate from statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET. The Act will be effective upon enactment and will expire five years later.
